body_html:
@chihuahua Nope this won't work. You would obtain something that's even weirder.

This is the graph:

A closer look:

The reason I think this is not the intended behavior is because. In some settings, it's really common to take a part of the computation graph as a module and take input from different sources. It turns out that Tensorboard does not recognize that the same part of the graph is used for different inputs. Thus it fails to use a common scope for them.

Update
I tried to use make_template to see this would work in that setting. But apparently it is not....

body:
@chihuahua Nope this won't work. You would obtain something that's even weirder.

This is the graph:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6040760/25756242/f0754a2c-31bd-11e7-8951-2ae16760e318.png)

A closer look:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6040760/25756118/81e85bee-31bd-11e7-9ad3-016893b18d14.png)

The reason I think this is not the intended behavior is because. In some settings, it's really common to take a part of the computation graph as a module and take input from different sources. It turns out that Tensorboard does not recognize that the same part of the graph is used for different inputs. Thus it fails to use a common scope for them.

**Update**
I tried to use [make_template](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/make_template) to see this would work in that setting. But apparently it is not....
